article.title: Concentration
article.paragraph: Inchemistry,concentrationis the abundance of a constituent divided by the total volume of a mixture. Several types of mathematical description can be distinguished:Concentration#Mass concentrationmass concentration,Concentration#Molar concentrationmolar concentration,Concentration#Number concentrationnumber concentration, andConcentration#Volume concentrationvolume concentration.GoldBookRefC01222concentrationThe term concentration can be applied to any kind of chemical mixture, but most frequently it refers to solutes and solvents insolutions. The molar (amount) concentration has variants such asnormal concentrationandosmotic concentration.
article.heading: Qualitative description

article.paragraph: Often in informal, non-technical language, concentration is described in aqualitative dataqualitativeway, through the use of adjectives such as "dilute" for solutions of relatively low concentration and "concentrated" for solutions of relatively high concentration. Toconcentratea solution, one must add moresolutionsolute(for example, alcohol), or reduce the amount ofsolvent(for example, water). By contrast, todilutea solution, one must add more solvent, or reduce the amount of solute. Unless two substances arefullymisciblethere exists a concentration at which no further solute will dissolve in a solution. At this point, the solution is said to beSaturation (chemistry)saturated. If additional solute is added to a saturated solution, it will not dissolve, except in certain circumstances, whensupersaturationmay occur. Instead,Phase (matter)#Phase separationphase separationwill occur, leading to coexisting phases, either completely separated or mixed as asuspension (chemistry)suspension. The point of saturation depends on many variables such as ambient temperature and the precise chemical nature of the solvent and solute.
article.heading: Quantitative notation
article.paragraph: There are four quantities that describe concentration:

article.paragraph: The molar concentrationc_iis defined as theamount of substanceamountof a constituentn_i(in moles) divided by the volume of the mixtureV:

article.heading: Related quantities
article.paragraph: Several other quantities can be used to describe the composition of a mixture. Note that these shouldnotbe called concentrations.
article.heading: Normality
article.paragraph: Normality is defined as the molar concentrationc_idivided by an equivalence factorf_\mathrm{eq}. Since the definition of the equivalence factor depends on context (which reaction is being studied),IUPACandNISTdiscourage the use of normality.
article.heading: Molality
article.paragraph: mainMolality(Not to be confused withMolarity)
The molality of a solutionb_iis defined as theamount of substanceamountof a constituentn_i(in moles) divided by the mass of the solventm_\mathrm{solvent}(notthe mass of the solution):
TheInternational System of UnitsSI unitfor molality is mol/kg.
article.heading: Mole fraction
article.paragraph: The mole fractionx_iis defined as theamount of substanceamountof a constituentn_i(in moles) divided by the total amount of all constituents in a mixturen_\mathrm{tot}:
TheInternational System of UnitsSI unitis mol/mol. However, the deprecatedparts-per notationis often used to describe small mole fractions.
article.heading: Mole ratio
article.paragraph: The mole ratior_iis defined as theamount of substanceamountof a constituentn_idivided by the total amount of allotherconstituents in a mixture:
Ifn_iis much smaller thann_\mathrm{tot}, the mole ratio is almost identical to the mole fraction.
TheInternational System of UnitsSI unitis mol/mol. However, the deprecatedparts-per notationis often used to describe small mole ratios.

article.heading: Dependence on volume
article.paragraph: Concentration depends on the variation of the volume of the solution due mainly to thermal expansion.
